Speaker: brown
Dialogue: God save the Queen!!

Speaker: assistant dresser
Dialogue: Sorry, ma'am.

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: Congratulations, Your Royal Highness!

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Thank you, Doctor.

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: A boy, I hear.  Excellent, excellent.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Yes.  Albert Victor.  Eddie for short.  What do you think?

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: A fine choice, sir.

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: Excellent!

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Are you riding up front?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I'll stay with the pony, thank you. She's all the way from Deeside and she's not sure she likes you yet.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: How many?

Speaker: lady ely
Dialogue: The Royal Family and senior members of the household, ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Just them?

Speaker: lady ely
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am.

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: We're expecting Brown this afternoon, ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Whom?

Speaker: princess alexandra
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I was due at a quarter past one.  You're late.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: Her Majesty's routine at Osborne House is not as you will remember it.  The Household remains in full mourning and no-one is permitted to raise their voice under any circumstances whatsoever.  As for the Queen's routine, she breakfasts at nine thirty, lunches at two,takes tea at five thirty and dinner at eight forty five.  No one is allowed to leave the building while the Queen is at home. On the rare occasions when she is out, you may ask permission to leave, but only with my consent. You're to be ready to walk the pony at any time after ten o'clock.  You'll clean her outdoor things and do any odd jobs as and when she requires.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: How will I know?

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: I'm sorry?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: How will I know what she requires?

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: You'll be sent a message.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Who'll bring it to me?

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: Her Highness' Equerry.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I need a man who knows where I am.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: I'm sure it won't be difficult to find you.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: That's not good enough.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: Then we'll have to see what can be arranged.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Aye, do.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: There is to be no communication with other members of the household on matters concerning the court except through myself or one of the Equerries.  No plans must be altered unless you are given prior authority by myself or a senior member of the household.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I came down at the Queen's request. I'll take my orders from her.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: In matters concerning the Household, I act on her behalf.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Do you?

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: Yes.  I do.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: So, is passing wind out of the question or do I need permission for that?

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: As I am sure you remember from Balmoral, you do not talk while in Her Majesty's presence unless Her Majesty addresses you directly.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Mr Brown.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: You are here safely.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Aye, ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: You are well?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: And the pony?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: She's well, too.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Your family sent cards.  It was much appreciated.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I'm glad of it.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: My husband was always very complimentary in speaking of you.  He would have approved, I am sure, of my calling on you in this way.  I trust it does not inconvenience you too much.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I've no family, ma'am, apart from my brothers and sisters.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Yes.  I forget his name.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Archie.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Yes.  That will be company for you.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: You do not - he ... get him out.  Get him out.  Get him out!

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: So the day they arrive, she greets the Sultan and his family with barely a word and then retires to her chamber. The Sultan, not used to State Occasions without a head of State, is standing in the lobby waiting for someone to tell him what to do.  But the court is under strict instructions not to talk in the corridors so nobody speaks to him, not a living soul, for the whole afternoon.  So now it's dinner and everyone's standing round the table -- still not a word -- waiting for Her Majesty to arrive. One hour goes by, two, the Sultan's getting a wee bit peckish to say the least.  So finally, his wee laddy breaks for the cold meats and stuffs a slice in his mouth.  Well, the uproar when she heard.  You'd have thought someone had stolen the crown jewels.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: So, there are rules.  Things you do and things you don't do.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I was just telling the woman how I feel, for God's sake.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: You don't tell Her Majesty how you feel.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I speak as I find, Archie.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: Not down south you don't.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I think he nearly ruptured his truss.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: How much?

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: Seventy a year.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Not bad, not bad.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: How about yourself?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Sixty.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: That's pretty good for a ghillie.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Prince Leopold?  Is he the one who bleeds all day?  So what does his valet do?  Wash his poultices for him?

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: It's better than shovelling horse shit.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: If you were looking for promotion, you should have picked one of the healthier ones.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: She's hardly a full hamper herself.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: It's only grief makes her like she is.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: Three years, John.  Is that not a bit long to be grieving?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: She loved him.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: Come on, man.  There's love and there's ...

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: You know what I mean.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I'm not sure I do, Archie.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: There's love and there's behaving like you do because there's nobody to tell you not to.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Which one of us is she flirting with?

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: The good-looking one.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Aye?  Then she's obviously not got enough to do.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: You work the system right, you could ask her yourself.  Just be thankful you're not working for Household.  The Queen never lets them out of her sight.  But wee spats like us can slip through the net, easy.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I'm no wee spat, ARCHIE.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Who is that?

Speaker: lady ely
Dialogue: It's Mr Brown, ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: What is he doing there?

Speaker: lady ely
Dialogue: He appears to be ... standing by his horse.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I made no request to go out riding today.  How long has he been there?

Speaker: lady ely
Dialogue: I don't know, ma'am.  He was observed earlier, I believe.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Sir Henry, Mr Brown is standing in the courtyard.  I have no wish to go riding.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: I'm very sorry, ma'am.  I can't imagine -- he was certainly given no instructions.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Please make sure it does not happen again.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: Of course, at once.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: What on earth did you think you were doing?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Awaiting my orders.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: You do not report for duty unless the Queen requests it.  You know that very well.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I didn't come all this way to sit on my arse.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: You will await your orders like everyone else.  Unless you prefer a repeat of yesterday's little excitement.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: I beg your pardon?

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: I thought I made myself perfectly clear.  You do not leave your room until Her Majesty requests it.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Well, you tell Her Majesty from me, if her husband was here now, he'd have had her out of that house and getting some air in her.  What the hell's the point in me being here otherwise?!

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: Go inside at once.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Is that the Queen's request?

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: Yes, it most certainly is!

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Mr Brown.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: You have been told repeatedly not to stand in the courtyard unless requested to do so.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Then why do you persist in doing it?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Because I think Her Majesty is wrong. If ever there was a poor soul who needed fresh air, it is her.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: The Queen will ride out if and when she chooses.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: And I intend to be there when she's ready.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Prince Albert was going to build a bench here.  He thought it one of the best views in Osborne.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: It's a fine spot, ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: He thought so, yes.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: If Prince Albert were here today, he'd tell him a thing or two.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Sir Henry is not alone.  They all wish it.  The same people who refused to grant my husband the title of King because he was deemed of insufficient rank--

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Aye, ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: bertie's valet
Dialogue: Mr. Carter, the Head Butler, sits there.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Not now he doesn't.  This is my place.

Speaker: bertie's valet
Dialogue: By whose authority?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: My own.

Speaker: bertie's valet
Dialogue: The order of seating at the Upper Servant's table is arranged personally by the Queen herself.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: That's a tautology lad.  If you say the Queen arranges something, you've no need to say she's done it personally.  That's understood.

Speaker: assistant dresser
Dialogue: Assistant, sir, yes.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: What's your name?

Speaker: assistant dresser
Dialogue: Mary Taylor, sir.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Have I seen you up in Balmoral, Mary?

Speaker: assistant dresser
Dialogue: I hope to go up next year.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: You wouldn't happen to know what the Queen's reading for recreation, would you, Mary?

Speaker: assistant dresser
Dialogue: Lord Tennyson, sir?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Am I the only one eating?

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: Lord Clarendon arrives, by invitation, at eleven o'clock, followed at twelve by a picnic in the grounds to celebrate Princess Alice's birthday. Dispatches, as usual, at two.  The Chancellor writes to say that, by happy coincidence, he will be in Cowes for the weekend.  He asks if Your Majesty might grant him an audience.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: He thought, perhaps, Your Majesty might wish to be informed of the latest developments in government.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: No.  I shall be out walking.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: Then perhaps Your Majesty might consider it opportune if the Prince of Wales were to meet him on your behalf?

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: On no account.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Mama, I really do think it's time we made ourselves a little more ... available.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Gesture?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I thought, a dinner for our ambassadors perhaps?

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Why are you dressed for outdoors?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: It's so infernally cold in here.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Cold is good--  Is that not so, Dr. Jenner?!

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: I'm sorry, ma'am?

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Cold is good!

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: Excellent, ma'am, excellent.  But perhaps if her Majesty were to consider accompanying her new-found physical vigor with the benefits of mental activity...

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Why am I being lectured in this way?!

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: Forgive me, Your Majesty.  In no way did I wish to suggest--

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I will not tolerate anybody lecturing me about the responsibility of the monarchy....

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Mother....

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: ... Least of all my son.  It was his irresponsibility that drove my husband to his grave.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: If it is inconvenient to Her Majesty, then perhaps she might consider allowing the Prince of Wales to host--

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I do believe they send so many boxes to taunt me. Doctor Jenner writes to them to say that my nerves are in an extremely fragile state and yet they continue to hound me with box after box after box after box after box!

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Don't potter, children.  Swim.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: You could buy that lot for garden ornaments and still see change from ten guineas.

Speaker: stanley
Dialogue: Have you seen this?

Speaker: stanley
Dialogue: Should we take it seriously?

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: The cartoon or Her Majesty's absenteeism?

Speaker: stanley
Dialogue: Well, both.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: The question is, do we need her?

Speaker: stanley
Dialogue: Surely, you're not suggesting we dispense--

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: My dear Stanley, a Prime Minister with only a handful of friends must respect public opinion.

Speaker: stanley
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: We'll see which way the wind blows.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: My heart's in the Highlands, my heart is not here!  My heart's in the Highlands a-chasing the deer!  Chasing the wild deer and following the roe! My heart's in the Highlands wherever I go!

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: One box of biscuits, one box of drop tablets, one box of pralines, sixteen chocolate sponges.  It's the same order every week, but does anybody bother to check it?  Now she has to travel all the way to Balmoral without the few luxuries she actually enjoys.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: So?  Someone'll send it on ahead.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Aye, but will they?

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: John, it's not your problem what she eats.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: The woman's surrounded by fools!  She has to be packed and ready to leave by seven thirty tomorrow morning.  Knowing that lot, they'll still be dressing her at eight.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: She's got an army of people to get her up and out.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: But I'm the only one she trusts.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: She'll blow hot and cold on you, John, she always does.  You want to be careful.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I'm on ninety pounds a year plus seventy pounds for a pile of tartan I'd be wearing anyway.  That's as much as a Page of the Back Stairs gets and that job's only for toffs.  I'm Her Majesty's Highland Servant! Indoors and Out.  There's no stopping me now.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: Oh God, not the pipes!

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: What are those?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Those, over there, there.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Craobhan-geanmchno-fhiadhaich.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: How can I possibly say that with a straight face?!

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Are they worth reading?

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I am told so.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Who by?

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Sir Henry Ponsonby tells me they are charming.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: What does he know about the Highlands?

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: He has been attending at Balmoral for many years.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: That doesn't make him an expert.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: His remarks were directed at the quality of the writing, not its subject.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I don't groom a horse to have it admired by others, I groom it because it needs grooming.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I do not do it for others.  But Ponsonby thinks they are good.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Just say what you have to say, woman. What other people think shouldn't matter to you.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Of course I shall say what I have to say.  I always do.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Aye, well, if all you want is a good opinion then he'd be sure to oblige you.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Literary appreciation does not begin and end with Tennyson.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: She'll be away on Friday between eight o'clock and six in the evening to visit the Grants in Glasalt.  If she's to make the journey there and back in the day she's to have no distractions the night before.  She'll take a light supper alone in her private drawing room and retire early.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: She'll need to sign dispatches before she retires.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: That can wait till the weekend.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: There are important papers from --

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: It can wait.  Anything else?

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: Are you sure Her Majesty is up to such a long journey?  She has only just recovered from a severe head cold.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: If I thought she wasn't up to it, I wouldn't let her go, would I?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Surely it is for the gentlemen to decide when to stop...

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: It is a disgusting habit, Bertie.  It should be discouraged.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Yes, but isn't midnight a little excessive?

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: It is quite late enough.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: But mama, the room was built expressly for that purpose.  It has been a smoking-room by tradition ever since father --

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Brown's responsibilities are onerous enough already.  He has far too much to do without having to stay up all night waiting for you to go to bed. The smoking-room will be closed and the lights put out at twelve o'clock.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Mama...

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: And that is my last word on the matter.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Well, I'm sorry, but I really do think it's too much that the gentlemen of the house should be dictated to by a servant.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: It's the Queen's decision.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I beg your pardon?  Mama...?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I think you should go now.  You've tired your mother enough.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: There's really no need for this.

Speaker: mrs grant
Dialogue: I'll not have her seeing it like it is!  I know she means well, but I wish she'd warn us she was coming.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: She thinks if she warned you, you'd go pouring water on the fire and stuffing the knitting under the sofa.

Speaker: mr grant
Dialogue: Aye, well, you can't stop a wife being house-proud.

Speaker: mrs grant
Dialogue: All right.  Show her in.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: They're ready now.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I hope they didn't go to any trouble, John.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Ah, well...

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Mr Grant.  How good it is to see you.

Speaker: mr grant
Dialogue: Your Majesty.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Mrs Grant.  How is your knee?  Has the pain eased a little?

Speaker: mrs grant
Dialogue: Oh not so bad, ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Good.  Oh and here are Douglas and John.  Haven't you grown?

Speaker: mrs grant
Dialogue: Growing all the time, ma'am.

Speaker: mr grant
Dialogue: Will you sit, ma'am?

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I know that!  That's Cairn Lochan.  We picnicked there once, did we not, John?

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Ah, the greasy pole.

Speaker: mary anne
Dialogue: Don't be facetious, dear. Remember your position.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: It's my position I'm thinking of.

Speaker: stanley
Dialogue: I see the Prince of Wales is here.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: I hope he got his mother's permission.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: And in your opinion?  Is she foolish?

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: La superstition met le monde entier en flammes.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Has anybody seen this ... Mr Brown?

Speaker: stanley
Dialogue: He is her personal servant, I believe.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: He would hardly make a very good personal assistant if he did not.

Speaker: mrs grant
Dialogue: ... it's not my best china.  I mean, it is my best china now, but the family set got stolen last summer.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Oh, I'm so sorry ...

Speaker: mrs grant
Dialogue: Of course it was no-one on the Estate. More likely one of the lads from Braemar.  Or further even.  I'll fetch the salt.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Mr Disraeli.  Ma'am.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Your Royal Highness.  What a pleasure to see you here.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Have you met Mr Lyle?  He's in sugar...?

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: I don't think I've had that pleasure.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: No doubt you've heard the rumors.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: I take no account of gossip, Your Highness.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: My concern is for the reputation of the Monarchy.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I fear the influence he has on her. The man's word is not to be credited. He is an arriviste of the very lowest water.  She's having a bust cast of him.  In Nero Marquino marble.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: I see.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I would talk to her myself, but she won't listen to me.  She must be persuaded, by someone she respects, to abandon this ridiculous favoritism before a situation develops.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: A situation?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I don't imagine you frequent the Republican Clubs.  But the fact that neither you nor I are members should not blind us to the significance of their existence.  The Tory Party has always been our party.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: I'm flattered you think so.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I tell you, if we don't stick together on this, you could find yourself First President's Opposition.  Du Royaum Uni.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Quite.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I don't think we can overstate the seriousness of this.

Speaker: stanley
Dialogue: What did he want?

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: To know when he'll be king.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: ... so Grant here and myself are riding over Lochnagar and the rain's pouring down in sheets and all we're thinking about is getting home for a drink, when through the gloom Grant spots a couple of poachers.  He gives me a shout and we chase them down towards the loch until Grant has your men up against the stacks and he's shouting and cursing at them, "Why are you poaching on Royal land?!"  And one of the little fellas looks up at him and says, "coz we've come up in the world."

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: Your Majesty!  Thank goodness you're safe!  I'll have a bath prepared immediately.  I recommend Macdonald's African Embrocation --

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Ah, pipe down, man.  The woman's fine.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: We stayed a little longer than expected with Mr and Mrs Grant.  It was most agreeable.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: We were expecting you to return by six.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: And now I am back.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: We took a nip of whiskey.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: To keep out the cold.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Aye.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Thank you, John.

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: She's drunk.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: No, she wasn't.

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: Surely not ...

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: Don't even think about it.

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: Pandora's Box ...

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: What is it, John?  John?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I heard something.

Speaker: journalist 1
Dialogue: Where did he get to?  I've lost him?

Speaker: journalist 2
Dialogue: I don't know if there's much worth writing about.

Speaker: journalist 1
Dialogue: Hard to tell.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: This close enough for you?  Go on!  On your way!  You filthy scavengers!

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: If I catch the miserable by-blow who told those men where she'd be, then I'll hang his balls to dry on Jock Wemyss, so I will!!

Speaker: bertie's valet
Dialogue: We --

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: You'll talk when I'm finished!

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: "Court Circular, Balmoral."  "On Tuesday, Mr John Brown enjoyed a display of sheep-dipping by local farmers.  On Wednesday, he attended a seance where he was pleased to listen to a recital of Auld Lang Syne by Mr Robert Burns himself ..."

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: If I find out that you had anything to do with this, I will have you sacked.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: I believe that decision rests with Her Majesty.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Don't think I can't persuade her.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: I don't doubt that the Queen was highly amused.  She has always had a very healthy sense of humor.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: This is a slur on her good name.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: In as much as the article is about yourself, I think you must now accept that the public has a right to its interest in you.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Nobody has any rights over me.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: We are all of us subject to forces beyond our control, Mr Brown, even you.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: You'll regret saying that.

Speaker: counter
Dialogue: Ayes to the right, three hundred and thirty, noes to the left, two hundred and sixty-five...

Speaker: dilke
Dialogue: Mr Speaker, I table a motion in furtherance of the Bill to Disestablish the Monarchy!

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: Order!  Order!!  ORDER!!!

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: We're going to lose.

Speaker: stanley
Dialogue: You can't know that for sure.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Gladstone's got his party facing the same way for the first time in years. We need help.  Where is the old girl?

Speaker: stanley
Dialogue: Who?

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Mrs Brown.

Speaker: stanley
Dialogue: It's questionable whether there's any advantage to be had from that direction.  She's never been less popular.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: In the press, perhaps.  But she's sold more copies of her Highland Journal in three months than Punch will ever sell in a year.  Time to wheel her out.

Speaker: stanley
Dialogue: She's refusing to leave Balmoral.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: What's her excuse this time?

Speaker: stanley
Dialogue: The Princess Louisa is too ill to move.  Frankly, the Queen's rather upset at the recent spate of bad publicity.  You're smiling.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: I was trying to imagine "rather upset."

Speaker: dean wellselly
Dialogue: Forgive me, gentlemen.  I'm late.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Not at all, Dean.  Good of you to spare the time.

Speaker: dean wellselly
Dialogue: I came as quickly as I could.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: You've seen the latest cartoon in Punch, I take it?

Speaker: dean wellselly
Dialogue: I beg your pardon?

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: One of our madder brethren in the house was calling for disestablishment of the monarchy.

Speaker: dean wellselly
Dialogue: Good Lord.

Speaker: stanley
Dialogue: I'm sure it won't come to that.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: I was just telling Stanley how vital it is that the nation should feel the visible influence of the Sovereign. As a reminder that Parliament, indeed my own ministry, depends on the will of the Queen.

Speaker: dean wellselly
Dialogue: I couldn't agree with you more, but I am only Dean of Windsor.  I don't understand what ...

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: We hear from Balmoral that Mr Brown is interesting Her Majesty in some of the forms of worship associated with ... low-church Presbyterian.

Speaker: dean wellselly
Dialogue: What can we do?

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Oh, several things.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Read it.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: Again?

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Read it!

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: "The Times wishes to join the rest of Her Majesty's loyal subjects in expressing its deep joy at the news that the Queen is soon to come out of her mourning."

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Who told them that?

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: I have no idea.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: I -- forgive me, ma'am, I am no wiser than yourself.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: No-one should think themselves wiser than me!  It is not for any of the Queen's subjects to presume to tell Her Majesty when and where She should come out of mourning.  It is the Queen's sorrow that keeps her secluded!  It is Her overwhelming amount of work and responsibility, work which She feels will soon wear her out entirely!

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: Your Majesty --

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: And now they attack Brown too.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: I wish to see my mother.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: She's busy.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Convey her a message.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: She's away to Windsor tomorrow.  Talk to her there.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Tell her the Prince of Wales wishes to speak with her urgently about matters concerning the press.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Are you deaf as well as stupid?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: What did you say?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I said, are you deaf as well as stupid?

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Do you know who you address, sir?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Whom you address.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: The future King!

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Well, everyone's entitled to their opinion.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: Out of my way!

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: LEAVE US ALONE, WHY DON'T YOU!!

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: You!  What's your business here?!

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Well, don't stand where you shouldn't!

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Must they always follow us?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I ordered it.  It's for your own safety.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Dear me, you'll be telling me to watch what I eat next.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Aye.  But there are Fenians reported on the mainland.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: The threat from the Irish is greatly exaggerated, I'm sure.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I'll decide when it's exaggerated.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Is anything the matter, John?  John?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Nothing's the matter.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Hey, Barney.

Speaker: barney
Dialogue: Mr Brown, sir --

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: It's cold out there tonight, Barney.

Speaker: barney
Dialogue: Yeah, yeah, I did.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Good man.  And is she all right?

Speaker: barney
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Good.  She's a good girl.  Aren't you? Yeah, she's a lovely girl.  And you know the Queen's riding tomorrow?

Speaker: barney
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Are you all right, Barney?

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: lady ely
Dialogue: Mr Brown is unable to attend today.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: lady ely
Dialogue: I believe he is unwell, ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Unwell?

Speaker: lady ely
Dialogue: I understand he was in a fight.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Has he been hurt?

Speaker: lady ely
Dialogue: I believe not, ma'am.  I understand -- he'd had rather too much to drink.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: You may go.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: And she sent no word down?

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: They said you were drunk.  Why don't you tell her the truth?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: She'll think it's her fault for keeping me.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: What are you doing?!

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I'm getting dressed.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: You've got three broken ribs, man!

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I've got my duties to attend to.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: Don't be an idiot!  You're in no fit state to go anywhere.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: She'll be worried about me.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: She'll get over it.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I can't let her down now, Archie.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: And when was the last time she put herself out for you?  Look, John, whatever she says to you now, in the end you're still a servant.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Oh, I'm much more than that.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: Aye, she may say that to you, but the woman can say what she wants.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: You watch your tongue.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: Come on, man, I'm telling you what you already know.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: You know nothing about her!

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: When are you gonna see it, John?  She doesn't give a damn about you.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: From the Queen!

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: Aye.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: She means it.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: She'll drop you.  When she's done with you, she'll drop you.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Get out.  Out!

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: ... to be followed by a visit from Lady Bridport.  She is keen to secure a place for her niece as Maid of Honor.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I am tired.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: There is one other matter.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: I have a letter, ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: From whom?

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: From Princess Helena and other members of your family.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: My family is quite capable of communicating with the Queen in person.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: They are demanding the dismissal of John Brown on grounds of drunkeness.

Speaker: dean wellselly
Dialogue: You wished to see me, ma'am?

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: My husband tried always to make me think more subtly.  Of course he taught me so much and I can never repay my debt to him, or the love I feel, even now.  But, in truth, I think I am someone who can only feel things while they are alive to me. For that reason, I know I do not have a subtle mind.  I know that.  But I work hard and I try to do my duty.  Friends close to me now.

Speaker: dean wellselly
Dialogue: Your Majesty, a settled resignation is more lasting proof of affection than active grief.  If the good Lord sees fit to bring one into contact with congenial fellow beings, one should not analyze one's reaction too deeply. To allow oneself to be comforted by someone else need not imply any disloyalty to the memory of the loved one.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Sir Henry.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: Ma'am?

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Please tell the Princess, and other signatories to this letter, that the Queen will not be dictated to, or made to alter, in any way, what she has found to answer for her comfort.  Do I make myself clear?

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: Ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: You may go.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I would like to get down.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am?

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I was told you were in a fight.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Has someone seen to those bruises?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Having considered my position here at court, I have come to the conclusion that it is in the best interest of Your Majesty that I should resign.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I do not accept.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I had foreseen that you would not. But Your Majesty should understand -- that my mind will not be changed in this.  I leave for Deeside --

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I cannot allow it because I cannot live without you.  Without you, I cannot find the strength to be who I must be.  Please.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I promise.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: How dare the Irish break with the Anglicans? If Albert were alive today he would never allow the Crown to give up Church patronage.  No, the Irish must be told, very firmly, to stay exactly where they are.  It is the thin edge of the wedge, Mr Disraeli.  Next, you will be telling me that the Crown no longer governs this nation.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Your Majesty remains at the very epicenter of governance.  As for your people, look no further than the sales of your Highland Journals to see in what affection the nation holds their Queen.  You sell even more copies than Mr Dickens.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: But I lack your prose, Mr Disraeli.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Of course I understand your concern. You miss your people.  And they miss you.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Then they may read about me.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Indeed, and for that they are eternally grateful.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Is that not enough?

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: In so many ways ... and yet it is your presence they crave.  A figurehead.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I never thought to be bullied by you, Mr Disraeli.  You, I thought, understood a widow's grief.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Forgive me, ma'am, I cannot speak for the nation, only for myself.  As Prime Minister I confess I miss your presence, but that is only an expression of my own selfish desires and I should not burden you with it.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I stay here because I am happy.  Is that such a terrible crime?

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: No, ma'am.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Time for your walk.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: This is my good John Brown.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I have asked him to show you a little of Highland life while you are with us at Balmoral.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: What brings you here?

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: A man can refuse only so many invitations from his Queen.  It was remiss of me not to come earlier.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: What do you know about the Highlands?

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: I am a blank sheet.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Do you hunt?

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Occasionally.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Dare say you can be taught.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: To shoot perhaps, but not to kill.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: If you hunt, you kill.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Well then, I'll do my best.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Always remember, you keep it tight to your shoulder, you absorb the kick. Aim for the head.  Then imagine it's Gladstone.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Quite.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: ... Back doors, West Wing.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Side doors, East Wing.

Speaker: assistant dresser
Dialogue: Checked and locked, sir.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Louder, girl!

Speaker: assistant dresser
Dialogue: Checked and locked, sir.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Kitchen and lower house.

Speaker: bertie's valet
Dialogue: Checked and locked, sir.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Back and upper corridors.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Front door.  Checked and locked.

Speaker: bertie's valet
Dialogue: Did you see any Irish assassins today, Mr Brown?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: There's not a soul here cares about that wee woman's safety except me! She'd die in a ditch if I wasn't there to look out for her --

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: What's this?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: It's a diary.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: Be careful who sees it.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: What do you take me for?

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: You should have someone look after you.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I'm all right.  I just need to rest up a wee bit.  The room ... You don't have to stay.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: The place is a mess.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I can't move to tidy.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: It's what the maids are for.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I'm not having some prattler going through my things.

Speaker: archie
Dialogue: Won't you give yourself a rest, John? She's other people to look out for her.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: She needs me, Archie.  She canna do without me, she said it to my face.  How can I stop now?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: You sent for me.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: I've been called back to London.  My last day.  I thought I might take a walk on Lochnagar.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Princes and Lords are but the breath of kings, An honest man's the noblest work of God.  You must miss such magnificent views.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I don't think about it.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Forgive me, I've called you out and you should have been resting.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I'm fine.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: You're injured.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: It's nothing.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Still, someone must attend you.  Your wife should not have let you out.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I'm not married.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: This is the top.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: I confess, I sometimes feel as if I am not married myself, I see my wife so little.  But I'm forgetting the rewards.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I wouldn't know.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Surely --

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: What I do, I do for my Queen.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Was there never ambition?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Maybe, once.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Then I envy yo.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: To have achieved one's ambition, or to have reconciled oneself to its limits, is a lifetime's work.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I do what I do.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: For Her Majesty.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Aye.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: But yourself?  What about John Brown?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I said.  I serve the Queen.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: No other aspiration?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: To see her safe.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: You will not be unaware of the threat now posed by Republicanism.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Why do you think I keep her here?

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: Ah, but therein lies the paradox.  It is her very isolation that encourages the malcontents.  The longer she is away, the stronger they become; and who, honestly, can promise security against that?  However many doors you lock, someone will always get in. Even here.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: The truth is, the Queen would be safer doing her duty and returning south to her public.  John Bull loves her and John Bull is her best defense.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Her mind is set.  She won't change now.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: She trusts you, John.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: They don't see it.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: See what?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: The threat.  I tell them, but they don't see it.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: They aren't as watchful as you.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Too busy looking after themselves.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: The greasy pole.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: No loyalty.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: No love.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I promised to protect her from people like you.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: For once in my life, I am not the issue.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: She'll never understand it.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: In time, she will.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: She'll think I betrayed her.

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: But others will know that you acted for the greater good.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I received a letter today from Mr Disraeli.  Parliament is calling for my return to public duties.  Why won't they let us be?

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: We can't always have what we wish.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Duty?!  You talk about duty?!

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: If duty and safety are served by the same end then, aye, I do.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I cannot believe you are saying this? You, who I have relied on all this time --

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Have I ever let you down before--?

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: -- You stand there and tell me it is my duty ... after all you promised me!

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I'm breaking no promises!

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: You are forcing me to do the very thing you know I fear most!

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: For god's sake, woman, I'm just trying to keep you safe!

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I will not hear any more about my safety!!  You made me a promise and now you have broken it!

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: -- When I took you out riding, come rain or shine, because I knew it was right for you, when I kept the bairns off your back so you could have a bit of peace, when I saw you safe from home to home and you didn't even know I was there...!  All I've ever thought about is you!

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Then why send me back to them?!

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Because I have to! (pause Will you no listen to me, woman?

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Do not presume to talk to your Queen in that manner.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: May I say, how glad I am to see Your Majesty so much recovered.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Where is my son?

Speaker: princess alexandra
Dialogue: Prince Albert is at Windsor, ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Why is he not here?

Speaker: princess alexandra
Dialogue: He is sick, ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Then why are you not with him?

Speaker: princess alexandra
Dialogue: You ordered all members of the Royal Family to attend you at Balmoral.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: What is the matter with him?

Speaker: princess alexandra
Dialogue: He has typhoid fever, ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: No.  You are mistaken.  Prince Albert, my husband, had typhoid fever.  I asked what was wrong with my son.

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: The same, your Majesty.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Why was I not informed?

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: I did not consider it wise, in the circumstances, to tax your nerves.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: How ill is he?

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: Better.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Should the good Lord see fit to spare my son, I will order a mass to be celebrated at St. George's.  The people must share with their Queen, her prayers and hopes for their future King.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: The Queen will be riding to St. George's on the fifth.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: I recommend Her Majesty uses the covered carriage with a full Horse Guard.  In the event of any disturbance I will ensure --

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I will ride to St. George's in an open carriage.  It is time the Queen was seen by her public.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: NO!!

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: ... all seven stone of the man, paddling madly towards us through a sea of Horse Guards, waving something that looks vaguely like a pen.  I thought he must be one of the mother's ardent readership in search of the Royal indenture...

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: I intend Brown to be rewarded with a special medal cast in gold.  It will be called The Devoted Service Medal.

Speaker: bertie
Dialogue: A toast.  Victoria Regina!

Speaker: everyone
Dialogue: Victoria Regina!

Speaker: disraeli
Dialogue: ... If the first great object of the Tory Party is to maintain the institutions of the country, the second is, in my opinion, to maintain the Empire of England ... the hereditary, the traditionary policy of the Tory Party.  Go to your homes, teach them these truths, which will soon be imprinted on the conscience of the land ...

Speaker: page
Dialogue: North woods, sir.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: God save the Queen!!

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: How long has he been this sick?

Speaker: lady ely
Dialogue: A few days, ma'am.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Why was I not told earlier?

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: You should never have gone out in such foul weather.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Someone has to look after you.  It could've been someone.  It was before.

Speaker: victoria
Dialogue: Yes.  Yes it was.

Speaker: brown
Dialogue: Don't be silly, woman.

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: Erysipelas.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: Not too protracted, I hope.

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: When he heard, the Prince of Wales threw the bust from the window of the Royal Gallery.  It took four hours to gather the fragments.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: The Queen wishes to publish an account of him.

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: Dear oh dear.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: We think she can be dissuaded.  Have you had a glance at the diary?

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: Quite.  I think I'd best take it back.

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: Some young page was boasting about having seen it.  Lucky.

Speaker: jenner
Dialogue: Well, no rest for the wicked, Henry.

Speaker: ponsonby
Dialogue: No, indeed.
